title: Thermal energy transfer - metal cube in water

content.question: A metal cube is heated until its temperature is <math alttext="200 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mn>200</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>C</mtext></math>. The metal cube is then submerged in water that has a temperature of <math alttext="35 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mn>35</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>C</mtext></math>. The system, which includes the metal cube and water, is isolated from its surroundings and is allowed to reach thermal equilibrium. A student claims that the temperature of the water will eventually increase to <math alttext="200 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mn>200</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>C</mtext></math>. Is the student’s claim correct? Why or why not?

choices.label: No, because the metal cube will transfer energy to the water until the metal cube reaches a temperature of <math alttext="35 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mn>35</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>C</mtext></math>.
No, because the metal cube cools down and the water and the metal cube have the same temperature in equilibrium.
Yes, because the cube will transfer all of its energy to the water.
Yes, because the equilibrium temperature is equal to the greater temperature of the two interacting materials.

content.answer: No, because the metal cube cools down and the water and the metal cube have the same temperature in equilibrium.
